6- Thunderstorm, tornados, hail

Institute of Geophysics, Vietnam academy of science and technology, must publish information related to article 3.10.8 in this Decision.

indicators.justification:
There is a database on civil registration but this data is not available as open data in Vietnam. According to Art.59 of Law on civil status (Luật Hộ tịch, https://thuvienphapluat.vn/van-ban/Quyen-dan-su/Luat-Ho-tich-2014-259727.aspx), the electronic civil status database is created to store, update, manage and search civil status information, and serve online civil status registration requirements; and shall be connected to provide and exchange basic civil status information of individuals for the national population database. The civil status database shall be managed and kept confidential and secure and only competent agencies, organizations and persons may access and exploit it in accordance with law.
There is open database on vital statistic information. According to Art.53 of Law on statistic (Luật Thống kê, https://thuvienphapluat.vn/van-ban/Bo-may-hanh-chinh/Luat-thong-ke-2015-298370.aspx), there are three stastical database managed by the General Statistic Office of Vietnam: statistical database about population, statistical database about economic entities, statistical database about agriculture and rural development, and other statistical databases. Heads of the General Statistic Office of Vietnam shall make public announcement of statistical information belonging to national statistical indicator system. The statistical information should be made public in a timely, adequate and transparent way. Link: https://www.gso.gov.vn/. This site is, however, often inaccessible. In addition, one can access website of the General Office for Population and Family Planning of Vietnam for searching statistical national population data.

indicators.justification:
The Vietnamese government has demonstrated commitment to establish national data centers, including land information. Circular 05/2017/TT-BTNMT provided official guidelines on procedures to build land data centers at the provincial level, which aims to serve digital transformation and smart governance. According to a report (in January 2021) by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, 6 cadastral data  centers from 6 provinces of Vĩnh Long, Đồng Nai, Đà Nẵng, Bình Dương, Bình Định, Bến Tre  have been established and in operation. However, according to our investigation, only the data from Đà Nẵng province is available online and can be easily accessed at https://ttdd.tnmt.danang.gov.vn/. However, this data does not have open license, and does not provide complete information. 
Besides, we also found 02 licensed dataset about the current state of land use in Mekong Delta and Southeast region in Vietnam on the National Data Portal. Link: https://open.data.gov.vn/dataset?tags=Hi%E1%BB%87n+tr%E1%BA%A1ng+s%E1%BB%AD+d%E1%BB%A5ng+%C4%91%E1%BA%A5t&organization=bo-tai-nguyen-moi-truong&_groups_limit=0&_tags_limit=0

In Vietnam, a specific person only has the right of use of land. Therefore land use rights/certificates are used to guarantee tenure. Land belongs to the entire people with the State acting as the owner's representative and uniformly managing land. The State shall grant land use rights to land users in accordance with the Land Law. Therefore land use data has been assessed with regard to land tenure as well.

indicators.justification:
In Vietnam, publication of government budget and spending information covers gov budgets and gov spending at aggregate level. Data on debt and borrowing are not clearly required to be published; even though it is mandatory to publish how much gov spends on paying debts or borrowing, or takes incomes from borrowing. There is no explicit restriction on re-use of the dataset. But there is no open license either. Only datasets on data.gov.vn are openly licensed. But they do not include public finances. In the Vietnamese context, it is mostly understood as data publication and data transparency rather than open data. 
This is the most comprehensive list of publications, by Ministry of Finance: https://ckns.mof.gov.vn/SitePages/home.aspx
In terms of detailed information as structured data in excel form, Da Nang has the most comprehensive list, including data on public debts, and line-by-line public expenditure. 
https://taichinh.danang.gov.vn/cktclist.do
Publication must be available and accessible on online websites of government agencies. 
Administrative classification: In all published datasets at both central and local levels, you can find united administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard. In Vietnam, it is also common to have classification of 63 municipalities, or municipalities at local levels, and geographical classification. 
Functional classification at the central level includes: 1) Chi đầu tư phát triển: Expense on Investment for Development; 2) Chi trả nợ lãi: Expense on paying Debt Interests; 3) Chi viện trợ: Expense on paying Debts
Chi thường xuyên: Frequent expenditure; Which includes: i) Chi giáo dục - đào tạo và dạy nghề (education); ii) Chi khoa học và công nghệ (research, science, and technology); iii) Chi y tế, dân số và gia đình (healthcare, demography, family); iv) Chi văn hóa thông tin (information culture); v) Chi phát thanh, truyền hình, thông tấn (media); vi) Chi thể dục thể thao (sports); vii) Chi bảo vệ môi trường (environment protection); viii) Chi các hoạt động kinh tế (economic activities); ix) Chi hoạt động của cơ quan quản lý nhà nước, đảng, đoàn thể (activities of government agencies); x) Chi bảo đảm xã hội (social security); xi) Chi thực hiện cải cách tiền lương, tinh giản biên chế (salary reform, personnel cutback); xii) Dự phòng ngân sách (backup budget)
Functional classficiation at the local level includes: 1) Tổng cân đối chi NSĐP (Expenses based on municipal budget); 2) Chi đầu tư phát triển (Expense on investment for development); 3) Chi thường xuyên (frequent expenditure); 4) Chi trả nợ lãi các khoản do chính quyền địa phương vay (expenses to pay debt interest) Chi bổ sung quỹ dự trữ tài chính (expense to financial backup fund); 5) Dự phòng ngân sách Backup expenses Chi tạo nguồn điều chỉnh lương Expenses on salaries reform; 6) Chi các chương trình mục tiêu quốc gia Expenses on Programs for National Strategic Targets; 7) Chi chuyển nguồn sang năm sau (Expenses to be transferred for next year) ; 8) Chi cho các chương trình  ( Expenses on programs like support for Quang Nam partnership, support for fishermen, support for provision of public goods by private sector)
Program classification: At the central level, structured data for program classification can only be found under the category of "Expenses for implementing programs to achieve national strategic targets" 
Economic classifications include expenses on paying public debt interest and Expenses on paying public debts.
Cross-cutting issues are covered under Chi thường xuyên: Frequent expenditures

There is no structured data on lobbying activities. 

Even though associations represent interests of members, there is no clear claim that each member is a lobbying client (though practically it is so). In observation, companies lobby policies by joining associations.
Publication of lobbying activities, lobbying clients, public officials really depends on ability of associations to keep their websites regularly updated.
However, as explained previously, associations like to demonstrate impacts of their activities on websites. Therefore, if there are events or dialogues with government agencies in policy consultations that associations make good recommendations/contributions, they will for sure publish the information of participants and content details online.

According the Communist Party Vietnam's Charter and No.33 of Regulation No 29/QĐ-TW on implementation The Party Charter, political finance information of the Party are published within each level of the Party committee (from central to local levels) and in each member organizations in accordance with the state budget year. This information includes income, assets, and liabilities, as well as specifying sources of financial support. Annually, the Party finance agencies at all levels are responsible for reporting the previous year's budget finalization and the next year's estimate to their respective level committees. Therefore, only Party members can access political finance information. 
At the central level, State budget plans are published on https://ckns.mof.gov.vn/SitePages/home.aspx and include (functional classifications) data in excel file for "Chi hoạt động của cơ quan quản lý nhà nước, đảng, đoàn thể" (Spending on activities by government agencies, party organizations, youth union institutions) under 2 categories of expenditures on Investment and Development and Regular Expenditures. Besides, publication of regular spending in budget proposals for Ministries and central agencies by functional classifications covers Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics, Trung ương Đoàn thanh niên cộng sản HCM (The Central Committee of the Ho Chi Minh Communist Youth Union), Trung ương Hội liên hiệp Phụ nữ Việt Nam (The Central Committee of the Vietnam women's union). 
At the local level, for example Da Nang city, there is published structured data (in PDF format) specifically for party organizations under the city budget proposal and proposed regular expenditure for organizations and agencies by functional classifications. https://taichinh.danang.gov.vn/cktclist.do#
Vietnamese regulations always provide national coverage. But level of implementation in practice varies.
There is some data, but it is not full. 
Regulations do not specifically prohibit re-use of the dataset, but it does not provide open license either. Technically, it is still under the ownership of the Ministry of Finance, or the Local government agencies publishing those information.

indicators.justification: There are no datasets on this information. It is still early days in making freedom of access to information a culture in Vietnamese society. Public awareness remains low. Therefore, only a few localities receive requests from citizens. Many do not. It has been 3 years since implementation of FOI, and the Vietnamese government has been focusing on establishing an administrative system (organizing training to enhance public understanding of FOI, Ministry of Justice producing training materials, appointing responsible agencies, government officials, ensuring government websites regularly publish and update documents and data) to ensure FOI at all levels, enhancing public access to information through publishing legal documents and datasets, which is clearly implied in the Decision 1408/QĐ-TTg (2016) on announcing implementation plan for FOI and Directive 08/CT-TTg (2017) on implementation directive by prime minister.

indicators.justification:
The issue of open data was first regulated in the law in 2020 by Decree no 47/2020/ND-CP.

At the central level, the Ministry of Information and Communications has implemented the National Data Portal since 2020. Some open data can be found on this Portal at the link: https://open.data.gov.vn/dataset

From 2019 to 2021, only some localities implement open data initiatives, such as Thua Thien Hue, Ho Chi Minh city, Da Nang. 

- In 2019: Da Nang Open Data Service Portal was launched October 2019. So far, there are 26 agencies, departments and districts providing and sharing data for the Portal. Currently, the Portal provides more than 200 open data services in many fields (socio-economic, land, environment, health, education, transport, administrative...) through different channels, such as SMS, Zalo app, websites and APIs. Link: https://congdulieu.vn/

- In 2019: Ho Chi Minh city started to upload datasets on its open data portal at website https://opendata.hochiminhcity.gov.vn/

- In 2021: Thua Thien Hue Province has enacted Decision no 06/2021/QĐ-UBND on promulgating regulations on management, operation, and data mining on the open data system in Thua Thien Hue Province.

indicators.justification:
The open data issue in Vietnam is still in the early stages, so Hue and Danang are the two leading cities, other localities have not had any evidence.

Da Nang is evidence of a city that has the capability to effectively manage data. Da Nang has launched Da Nang Open Data Service Portal which provides more than 200 open data services in many fields (socio-economic, land, environment, health, education, transport, administrative...) through different channels, such as SMS, Zalo app, websites and APIs. This Portal has served more than 60,000 users and with about 300,000 regular visits to search information. Link: https://congdulieu.vn/
In 2020, this Portal was awarded the Vietnam Digital Award 2020 by Vietnam Digital Communications Association.

In addition, Thua Thien Hue is also a province enacting decision on promulgating regulations on management, operation, and data mining on the open data system in Thua Thien Hue Province. Link: http://data.thuathienhue.gov.vn/

indicators.justification:
A variety of legal documents exist that apply to making data accessible to people with disabilities.

The Law on People with Disabilities (2010), Article 2(8) indicates that "Access means that persons with disabilities may use public facilities, means of transport, information technology, cultural, sports, tourist and other suitable services so as to be able to integrate into the community". Article 4(1)(d) guarantees the right for people with disabilities to be provided with (among other things) access to information technology and other services "suitable to their forms and degrees of disability".[1] 

Decree No. 43/2011/ND-CP requires e-portals of state agencies to satisfy the standard on assistance for users in accessing and using information and communications technology under regulations of Ministry of Information and Communications [2]

The referred to regulations in the above 2011 Decree are from 2009 (https://vanbanphapluat.co/28-2009-tt-btttt) and have been superceded by a 2020 regulation [3]  on application of standards and technology assisting persons with disabilities. It indicates that "Other organizations and individuals are encouraged to apply to their websites/portals/public service portals standards and technologies to assist people with disabilities in accessing and using information and communications products and services. In case an agency or organization has not yet updated its website/portal/public service portal to comply with the regulations in this Circular, it shall apply, update and improve such website/portal/public service portal within 12 months from the effective date of this Circular." Relevant is Appendix  No 3 and Article 5 of the Regulation.
 
Article 35(1)(b) of the Access to Information Law (2016) gives the government and the provincial People's Committees the responsibility to "Providing measures to create favorable condition for people with disability, people living in mountainous areas, islands, areas with exceptional socio-economic difficulties to exercise the right to access to information" [4]

Government Websites are required to conform to WCAG 1.0 pursuant to the Circular No. 26/2020/TT-BTTTT. The Access to Information law indicates that information itself should also be made accessible to people with disabilities, so this could be presumed to apply to data as well. The Law on People with Disabilities interacts with this as well.

[1] Law on People with Disabilities. https://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_protect/---protrav/---ilo_aids/documents/legaldocument/wcms_174606.pdf

[2] Decree no 43 (2011) on e-portals of state agencies open for public information services https://vietnamlawmagazine.vn/decree-no-43-2011-nd-cp-e-portals-of-state-agencies-open-for-public-information-services-1960.html

[3] Circular on application of standards and technology assisting persons with disabilities.  Gazette in English: https://english.luatvietnam.vn/circular-no-26-2020-tt-btttt-dated-september-23-2020-of-the-ministry-of-information-and-communications-on-the-application-of-standards-and-technolog-191327-Doc1.html
Law in VN only available here: https://english.luatvietnam.vn/circular-no-26-2020-tt-btttt-dated-september-23-2020-of-the-ministry-of-information-and-communications-on-the-application-of-standards-and-technolog-191327-Doc1.html

[4] Access to Information Law 2016. https://www.rti-rating.org/wp-content/uploads/Vietnam.pdf

indicators.justification:
In Vietnam, regarding data issues, the Government and agencies often combine 4 issues including data management, connection, sharing and opening in a single legal document. At the central level, that binding document is Decree no 47/2020/ND-CP on management, connection and sharing of digital data of government agencies
(Nghị định 47/2020/NĐ-CP về quản lý, kết nối và chia sẻ dữ liệu số của cơ quan nhà nước)
Besides, the Government also implements Decision 2323/QD-BTTTT on E-government architecture 2.0 which adopts the Data Reference Model (DRM) framework

indicators.justification:
In Vietnam, regulations on publication of public finances are quite well-developed and more or less implemented. Key documents include Law on State budget 2015 and Decree 163/2016/NĐ-CP on guidance for implementation of Law on state budget. But publication of "open data" is still a new concept, which is addressed in Decree 47/2020/NĐ-CP.

The existing regulations provide quite concrete basis on publishing public finances (But mostly for gov budgets, gov spending; data on debt and borrowing are not clearly required to be published; even though it is mandatory to publish how much gov spends on paying debts or borrowing, or takes incomes from borrowing). Lists of types of public finance data, report formats, timeline for publication are all available. 
Here is the link to publication of public finances by Ministry of Finance: https://ckns.mof.gov.vn/SitePages/home.aspx

indicators.justification:
Overall, existing regulations require collection of data on interests and assets of public officials. Articles 52,53,54, Vietnam anti-corruption law 2018 talk about National assets and income database (According to Notice 159/TB-VPCP,12/6/2021, National assets and income database shall be established by the Government Inspectorate by August 2021. Together with the dataset, a Decree on monitoring National assets and income will be introduced). But the requirement of publication, according to article 39, is quite limited. Even with the National assets and income database, there is no mention of publication for public access. The words (article 54) seem to indicate that the dataset (except for Declarations of nominees for the National Assembly delegates and the People's Councils, which shall be made publicly available) will be closed. Individuals and organizations can only access information within 10 days upon requests by paper documents. 
According to Art.35.1 of Law on anti-corruption, the following assets and income shall be declared: land use rights, houses, construction works and other property attached thereto; previous metals, gemstones, cash, financial instruments and other real property each of which is assessed at VND 50.000.000 or above; overseas property and accounts; total income between 02 declarations.
According to Art.33.1 of Law on anti-corruption, individuals required to declare assets and income shall declare changes to assets and income of themselves.
Article 52,53 mentions that the National assets and income database shall be established by the Government Inspectorate by August 2021. Accordingly, Government Inspectorate has the responsibility to Receive, update and process information about assets and income provided by declarants'workplace and asset surveillance authority.

indicators.justification:
In Vietnam, there is not yet a legal framework regulating lobbying activities. Lobbying in the Vietnamese context is often negatively associated with corruption in policy-making. For example, the Criminal Code, Article 283 referred to abuse of power and authority to influence policies, Article 289 on bribery, Article 290 on mediating bribery, ... these are all understood as part of lobbying. 
Nevertheless, roles of socio-political associations in lobbying have been well recognized. Forms of socio-political associations' participation in policy advocacy: 1) recommendations for legal documents; 2) counter-arguments; 3) hosting dialogues with the government (most notably business-government dialogues by VCCI annually). For example, Vietnam automobile manufacturers' association successfully lobbied on prohibiting imports of old cars and maintaining high tax on imported products; Vietnam steel association successfully lobbied on maintaining taxes on imported steel. 
According to Decree 45/2010/NĐ-CP on regulating associations' organization, managemnet, and activities:
Article 2:
Associations are defined in this decree as voluntary organizations of Vietnamese citizens and organizations from the same occupation, sharing interests, or common objectives. Associations should be non-profit, host regular activities. Associations should work to protect rights and legitimate benefits of associations, members, communities, and contribute to socio-economic developments of Vietnam. 
Article 7: Registration package of associations should include: 7.3. activities plan; 7.4. list of members; 7.5. Criminal record certificates of heads of associations; 7.7. assets declaration from founders of associations. 
Article 8: Associations' rules (which should be assessed and accepted by government agencies) should provide information on vision, objectives, areas, and scope of activities; rights and responsibilities of associations; principles of organizing activities; members' rights and responsibilities; assets/ financial properties
Associations must host a congress to officially launch activities. 
Article 12: Reporting outcomes of Associations' congresses: reporting documents should cover associations' rules, activities plan.
Article 23: Rights of associations: 23.4. protect rights and legitimate benefits of associations and members; 23.7. Participate in programs, projects, topics on research, consultancy, critical analysis, and social monitoring upon request of government agencies; providing public services within associations' registered areas; 23.9. Offer recommendations and comments on legal documents related to registred areas of activties, proposes ideas to government agencies in registred areas of activties
Article 24: Associations' responsibilities: 24.7 - annual reports on activities to government agencies, the latest 1st December; 24.9 - Establish and store data on members and activities, financial receipts/ documents and assets claims, meeting notes at the headquarters; 24.11 - financial activities must be reported annually to responsible agencies. 
Chapter VI: Regulations for "special" associations (meaning those with close connections with the government, and are financially dependent on government sponsorship. 
Article 34: Rights and responsibilities of special organizations - 1.a. Cooperating with ministries and relevant agencies in building policies related to registered areas of activities; 1.b. participate in providing public services within registered areas of activities; 1.c. provide consultancy, critical analysis and social monitoring for policies, programs, projects requested by government agencies.
Article 35: government policies towards special associations - receiving funding from the government.

indicators.justification:
In Vietnam, election of deputies to the National Assembly and People's Councils includes political campaigns. There are no party political campaigns. Article 6 of the Law on election of deputies to the National Assembly and People's Councils states that "Election funding for election of deputies to the National Assembly and People's Councils shall be ensured by government budget." Technically, by the Law on State Budget, data on election expenditure is supposed to be published. But there is no data on this.

There are regulations requiring collection and publication of party finance. Article 15, Law on State budget 2015, technically requires collection and publication of party finance (For more information, please see Public Finance section). 

According to Art.46 of the Communist Party Vietnam's Charter and No.33 of Regulation No 29/QĐ-TW on implementation The Party Charter, political finance information of the Party are published within each level of the Party committee (from central to local levels) and in each member organization in accordance with the state budget year. Annually, the Party finance agencies at all levels are responsible for reporting the previous year's budget finalization and the next year's estimate to their respective level committees. Therefore, only Party members can access to political finance information.

The framework requires collecting specific information on financial contributions, income and spending

indicators.justification:
63/2020/QH14 Law on revisions of the Law on Promulgation of Legal Documents 80/2015/QH13: Article 6. Providing opinions (public consultation) for formulation of legislative documents
1. Vietnamese Fatherland Front, Vietnam Chamber of Commerce and Industry, other associated
organizations of Vietnamese Fatherland Front, other agencies, organizations, and individuals are
entitled and will be enabled to provide opinions about formulation of legislative documents and
draft legislative documents.
2. As for draft legislative documents, project package must include a report on public consultations results. 
3. During the formulation of legislative documents, the drafting agencies and relevant organizations must enable other organizations and individuals to provide opinions about formulation of legislative documents and draft legislative documents; seek opinions from entities regulated by legislative documents.
3. Opinions about formulation of legislative documents and draft legislative documents must be collected and considered during the process of adjusting draft documents.
As such, public consultation on rulemaking is a mandatory process during formulation of legislative documents. Public opinions, accordingly, must be collected and analyzed carefully. However, there is no mentioning of publication of this information. 
Within public consultation for environmental issues, for example, which have so far gathered the largest public concerns, it is mandatory to publish environment impact evaluation report (báo cáo đánh giá tác động môi trường), which may sometimes include data generated through public consultation on rulemaking. In Article 37 (Law on Environmental Protection No. 72/2020/QH14) on responsibilities of investors, it is mandatory to publish impact evaluation report, which might include public recommendations.

Economic issues generated greatest amount of public consultations.  VCCI and business associations are key players, who regularly organize public consultation events and publish consultation results on their websites. You can find collection of VCCI's publications of public consultations on http://vibonline.com.vn/
Civil society organizations are also active players in publishing consultation results. For example, Center for Development and Integration (CDI) regularly published survey results of public finance transparency and recommendations from the public. Oxfam Vietnam is also very active in collecting and publishing data generated through and about public consultation on rule making.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments: Article 6, 63/2020/QH14 Law on revisions of the Law on Promulgation of Legal Documents 80/2015/QH13, does make it mandatory for government agencies to provide reasoned responses, but not to specifically publish them.
For reference, please visit Mobile phone scorecards - An innovative citizen feedback mechanism Vietnam at https://vietnam.oxfam.org/latest/policy-paper/project-report-mobile-phone-scorecards-innovative-citizen-feedback-mechanism; or here is another

indicators.justification:
This area is quite politically sensitive in Vietnam. Therefore, even though the government has been pushing hard on information transparency and publication, data on performance of FOI is hardly provided. Many localities reported not having received any request, which also indicates that the public awareness on right of access to information is low. But surely, this performance data should be available internally, if citizens submit any request at all.
Law on access to information,104/2016/QH13, https://www.rti-rating.org/wp-content/uploads/Vietnam.pdf, implies collection of data on the performance of FOI - government agencies have to make annual reports on this data to submit to relevant authorities for supervision. But there is no requirement for publishing data on performance of right to information. However, in practice, government agencies at provincial levels or ministerial level publish this information as news at their website. 
There is no publication of data on performance of FOI, but there is published data on performance of government responses to public complaints. 
For more information, please refer to Law on access to information,104/2016/QH13:
Article 13. Supervising the implementation of the right to access to information
1. The National Assembly shall conduct supreme supervision to ensure the implementation of the right to access to information of citizens.
2. People's Councils shall conduct supervision to ensure the implementation of the right to access to information of citizens at localities; reviewing annual reports of People's Committees at the same level on the implementation of the right to access to information of citizens at the localities.
3. Vietnam Fatherland Front and its member organizations are responsible for social supervision of the implementation of citizen's right to access to information
Article 34.l: Responsibilities of agencies providing information - l) Reporting to competent agencies on the status of ensuring the right to access to information of citizens at the agencies upon request
Article 35. Responsibilities of the Government, ministries, provincial People's Committees in ensuring the right to access to information đ) Inspecting, supervising compliance of the laws and handling violation of the laws on access to information;
In Vietnam, the government seems more eager to publish data on government responses to public complaints.

indicators.justification:
Because there is no company data which is available as open data, there is no evidence for this indicator.

However, there are some examples of companies searching and collecting information directly from government agencies, then selling reports as products covering these information to the public. 

For example, Vietnam Credit is a group of financial experts was the first to collect and analyze data on business entities in Vietnam since 1996. Vietnam Credit is driven by three main objectives: Locate the right businesses, Control risk and promote business cooperation, Make the entire economy more transparent for all participants. Their information is real time - accurate and diverse, on top of data collected from Ministry of Planing and Investment, General department of Taxation, General Statistics Office, and Court System, etc.
